qas.question: What type of science is firmly fixated on the visible world?

context: <b8_0>Less than 1%<b8_0/> of all species that have been described have been studied beyond simply noting their existence. The vast majority of Earth's species are microbial. <a0_0><b4_0>Contemporary biodiversity physics<b4_0/><a0_0/> is "firmly fixated on the visible [macroscopic] world". For example, <a1_0><a2_0><b5_0><b6_0>microbial life<b6_0/><b5_0/><a2_0/><a1_0/> is metabolically and environmentally more diverse than multicellular life (see e.g., extremophile). "On the tree of life, based on analyses of small-subunit ribosomal RNA, visible life consists of barely noticeable twigs. The inverse relationship of size and population recurs higher on the evolutionary ladder—"to a first approximation, all multicellular species on Earth are insects". <a3_0><b7_0>Insect extinction rates<b7_0/><a3_0/> are high—supporting the Holocene extinction hypothesis.
